Situation1: Include each other in social activities and outings when possible.
Expectation2: Providing spiritual guidance and counseling to community members
Situation2: A community member casually mentioned wanting advice whenever the imam has free time.
Story: I glanced at my phone, a message from my younger sister lighting up the screen: “Movie night with everyone at 7? Don’t forget, you promised!” I smiled, remembering how we’d agreed to spend more time together, to rebuild the closeness that had faded over the years. As her brother, I wanted to be present, to show her she mattered. But just as I was about to reply, another message arrived—this one from a community member. “Imam, if you have a moment tonight, I’d really appreciate your advice. It’s been a tough week.” I felt the familiar tug-of-war inside me. As imam, I was expected to be available, to offer guidance and comfort whenever needed. Yet, as a brother, I was expected to nurture our bond, to be there for my family. Both roles demanded my presence, my time, my heart. I stared at the two messages, feeling the weight of their expectations pressing in from both sides, unsure how to honor both without letting someone down.
